apple: Seeds arranged in a central core
specific colors like red, green, or yellow
aquarium_fish: Distinctive colors and patterns found in fish species
Aquatic environment, often with water, plants, and/or gravel
baby: more chubby and less defined limbs
bear: Longer snout with a more pronounced nose
bed: bed linens such as sheets, blankets, or pillows
absence of human features (e.g., limbs, face, clothing)
bedding such as sheets, blankets, and pillows
bee: overall body shape (more streamlined and less segmented than most beetles)
beetle: often has wings under hard wing covers (elytra)
Wings that fold vertically over their backs when at rest
Long, slender antennae with clubbed tips
Presence of wings (beetles often have elytra, hard wing covers)
bicycle: Frame with a chain and gears
bottle: Transparent or translucent material (such as glass or plastic)
Transparent or semi-transparent material (usually glass or plastic)
bowl: Often placed on a flat surface like a table
boy: Lack of traditionally feminine accessories (e.g., hair clips, necklaces)
Presence of teeth: Boys have more and larger teeth, while babies may have few or no teeth.
Short hair styles (although girls can also have short hair)
bridge: large scale spanning a body of water or land
absence of human features like facial characteristics or limbs
Architectural elements like trusses, cables, or beams
bus: Different body design, often with an articulated or double-decker structure
side mirrors (buses typically have side mirrors for the driver to check traffic, while trains do not)
size (buses are generally smaller than train cars)
camel: Desert or arid background (often indicating the natural habitat of a camel)
One or two humps on the back
can: consistent size (typically much smaller than a human)
labels or printed design on the surface
absence of human characteristics such as limbs, face, and clothing
caterpillar: Numerous small prolegs (false legs) along its body
distinct segments and possibly colorful patterns on the body
chimpanzee: Hands and feet with fingers and toes
clock: Located typically on walls, tables, or inside buildings
hour and minute hands (sometimes a second hand)
Presence of gears or digital display
cloud: no solid structure or defined edges
can appear fluffy or wispy in texture
cockroach: Presence of head, thorax, and abdomen sections
couch: upholstery that matches the room decor
crab: Exoskeleton texture: Crabs typically have a rougher, more textured exoskeleton compared to the smoother exoskeleton of many beetles.
Often observed on the seafloor or near coastal areas
paddle-like back legs (in some species, adapted for swimming)
Eyes: Crabs usually have stalked eyes that are set further apart, while beetles have compound eyes that are typically closer together.
crocodile: Short, sturdy legs with webbed feet
Eyes and nostrils positioned on top of the head
cup: Design: Cups might have printed patterns, logos, or colors that differ from the uniform metallic appearance of a can.
Made of diverse materials (ceramic, glass, plastic, metal)
dinosaur: often in an outdoor, prehistoric setting
flatfish: both eyes on one side of the body
typically a brown, grey, or sandy color
forest: presence of wildlife such as birds, squirrels, or deer
fox: Reddish or orange fur color (commonly for red foxes)
hamster: Soft, fine fur covering the entire body
often found in a habitat like a cage or hamster wheel
**Fur**: Hamsters typically have thicker, fluffier fur.
keyboard: Presence of function keys (F1, F2, etc.)
lawn_mower: Purpose: Lawn mowers are designed for cutting grass and have grass collection bags or side-discharge chutes. Tanks are built for combat and have visible weaponry, like cannons or machine guns.
User walking behind or riding on it
more than two wheels (typically four for riding mowers)
Lack of human facial features and limbs
leopard: Long tail with a tapered end
Size relative to environment (much larger than a spider)
lion: Eyes and ears positioned on a mammalian face
lizard: the presence of a head with distinct ear openings
Presence of habitats like rocks or terrariums
posture and body structure (lizards are typically squatter with legs splayed outward)
man: Presence of accessories often worn by adults, such as a watch or glasses
maple_tree: Overall shape and size of the tree canopy
Leaves (often with a distinct shape, generally lobed)
palmate leaves with multiple pointed lobes
motorcycle: frame made of metal and other materials associated with vehicles
Absence of fur, ears, and tail
mountain: Geological features like cliffs, ridges, and valleys
Natural elements like clouds or skies in the background
treeline or zones of vegetation that change with altitude
mouse: Fur that covers more of the body, including the tail
mushroom: Central stalk (stem) that may be cylindrical or have variations in thickness
Color variation: Mushrooms can come in many colors, but their colors are usually more uniform and not as patterned as a snake's scales.
orange: stem remnants or small indent on one side
orchid: presence of multiple blooms on a single stalk
Petals and sepals forming unique shapes
otter: presence of a tail (short and thick for otters, long and smooth for dolphins)
use of paws to hold food or tools
pear: Tapered shape with a wider bottom and narrow top
Color: Pears are typically green, yellow, or brown, while mice are usually shades of gray or brown.
lack of any labeling or text
pickup_truck: flatbed or open cargo area behind the cab
presence of a front grille and headlamps for highway driving
Presence of doors, windows, headlights, and a grille
pine_tree: Visible trunk of a solitary tree
Dark green color of the needles
plain: Uniform vegetation spread over a large area
Lack of structures like buildings or roads
plate: Absence of facial features, hair, limbs, or clothing
Light weight and easy to handle
poppy: Large, showy flowers with delicate petals
porcupine: Short limbs and small, rounded snout
Rounder face with a shorter snout
sharp, protective quills covering the back and tail
possum: No distinctive white stripe(s) along the back
Five-fingered paws with opposable thumbs on the hind feet
rabbit: Natural, organic setting like grass or burrows
raccoon: four legs with noticeable paws and claws
ringed tail with alternating dark and light bands
ray: Presence of gills and spiracles for breathing
presence of gill slits on the underside
absence of facial features common to humans (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth in a human face arrangement)
rocket: cylindrical body with a tapered end
fins or stabilizers at the base
rose: Bright, varied colors (e.g., red, pink, white, yellow)
Presence in a garden or bouquet
sea: Presence of boats, marine creatures, or beach elements
seal: Absence of dorsal fin (seals lack the prominent dorsal fin that dolphins have)
Body shape (seals have a more streamlined, torpedo-shaped body)
Presence of external ears (in some seal species)
Body shape: Seals have a more streamlined, elongated body shape, while turtles have a hard, rounded shell.
shark: Mouth Position: A shark's mouth is typically located on the underside of its head, while a whale's mouth is located on the front of the head.
Eyes positioned on the sides of the head
Gill Slits: Sharks have multiple visible gill slits on the sides of their heads, typically five to seven, whereas whales have a single blowhole or pair of blowholes on top of their heads.
skunk: Distinctive black and white coloration (typically a white stripe or V-shape pattern on black fur)
Typically a more compact and low-to-the-ground posture
snail: Shell shape: Snails typically have a spiral-shaped shell, while crabs have a more flattened, broad shell.
Slimy Trail: Snails leave a mucous trail as they move.
Shell: Snails have a noticeable external shell, while worms do not.
snake: presence of ventral scales (on the belly)
presence of a head with eyes and a forked tongue
spider: Segmental body (with a cephalothorax and abdomen)
squirrel: Climbing behavior, often seen in trees
a more upright posture (often seen standing on hind legs)
streetcar: Boarding platforms or stops along the tracks
sunflower: Smaller, individual flowers within the disk
central disk composed of tiny florets
sweet_pepper: Bright, solid colors (e.g., red, green, yellow, orange)
no eyes or visible body segments
Larger size compared to rocket leaves
table: various materials such as wood, metal, or glass
Variety of shapes, such as rectangular, round, or square
does not contain rooms or walls
tank: Usually larger size and extended length
telephone: Buttons for functions such as redial, hold, or speaker (for modern telephones)
presence of buttons with numbers/letters or touchscreen icons
base unit with cradle for the handset
television: buttons or ports on the frame
tiger: Four legs with paws and claws
tractor: Distinctive large rear wheels (common in many tractors)
Manufacturer emblem or model name typical of agricultural equipment brands (e.g., John Deere, Case IH)
train: Multiple doors: Trains have multiple doors along the sides for passenger entry, compared to usually fewer on a bus.
tulip: Presence of leaves around the stem
turtle: clear segmentation between body parts (head, shell, limbs)
a generally rounded or oval body shape
wardrobe: typically situated in a bedroom or dressing room
Placement against a wall or as part of furniture setup
designed for storage of garments and accessories
whale: blowhole on top of the head
blowholes on top of the head
willow_tree: Natural outdoor setting with soil, grass, or water around the base of the willow tree
Branches that form a graceful, curved shape
Absence of fruit (specifically apples) hanging from branches
wolf: Muzzle that is broader and shorter
Canine-like face with a long muzzle
woman: Engaging in activities typical of adults (e.g., driving, working, conversing)
worm: **Absence of Scales**: Worms have smooth, moist skin, whereas snakes have dry, scaly skin.
movement (if visible in a series of photos)
